thread.title: NCAA College Football Frenzy -- Sort-of Separation Saturday
thread.title_full: NCAA College Football Frenzy -- Sort-of Separation Saturday

title: NCAA College Football Frenzy -- Sort-of Separation Saturday
text: It was billed as Separation Saturday. A day meant to separate the contenders from the pretenders in the NCAA football world. Good-bye, Michigan. See ya, Florida. So long, Texas A&M. OK, so maybe there wasn’t as much separation as there could have been in the three games involving six of the top 12-ranked college pigskin squads. That’s especially true of the No. 5 Michigan State Spartans and the No. 12 Michigan Wolverines. The Big Ten rivals went down to the wire, and only a crazy ending put Sparty in the win column — a fumble by Michigan punter Blake O’Neill, who was trying to grab a low snap, was returned for the winning points on the final play of the game. Jalen Watts-Jackson somehow bullied his way into the endzone from 38 yards out for that bizarre touchdown at the buzzer for a 27-23 shocker by Michigan State (7-0) over host Big Blue (5-2) at a stunned Big House in Ann Arbor, Mich.“What do you say?” Spartans head coach Mark Dantonio told ESPN post-game. “You gotta believe, I guess. We kept talking about being mentally strong and just keep playing. Unbelievable. “I guess we won on a crazy play, but we played hard and with conviction, and that’s what we asked our guys to do,” Dantonio continued. “We’re 7-0. We advance — that’s what it means. In the big picture, our (national title) dreams are still alive.” In College Station, Texas, the No. 10 Alabama Crimson Tide (6-1) rolled up a 41-23 victory over the No. 9 Texas A&M Aggies (5-1), but turnovers for TDs marred the game in the visiting team’s favour. Turns out Aggies QB Kyle Allen is no Johnny Manziel, who earned his Heisman Trophy as a freshman pivot for A&M three years ago with a signature win over the Crimson Tide. Allen, who threw 20-of-40 for 263 yards and one TD, had his issues. Try three interceptions returned by Alabama for touchdowns. Tide freshman Minkah Fitzpatrick had two of them — a 33-yard one to open scoring and a 55-yard one to wrap up the day. In between time, a 93-yard pick-six by ’Bama’s Eddie Jackson in the second quarter put the Tide up three TDs. It didn’t hurt either that ’Bama running back Derrick Henry scampered to a career-high 236 yards and two TDs on 32 carries in what was a well-controlled game by the visitors.“This is a great team win,” Tide head coach Nick Saban told CBS’ Allie LaForce post-game. “The turnovers in the game were huge. There were a lot of big plays in the game — our interceptions, and they had a punt return for a touchdown (of 68 yards by Christian Kirk).” The late game saw the No. 6 LSU Tigers, behind Heisman Trophy-frontrunner Leonard Fournette’s 180-yard, two-TD effort, edge the No. 8 Florida Gators 35-28 in a hotly-contested tilt. Bottom line: The losers won’t be falling too far in the standings and still may be able to play their way back in to College Football Playoff consideration. SECOND & LONG Curious that the Crimson Tide were somehow demoted to 10th spot in the AP Top 25 last weekend despite taking care of the stubborn SEC-rival Arkansas Razorbacks 27-14. They tumbled two spots in the rankings, while Texas A&M stuck at No. 9 and Florida rose two spots to No. 8, essentially meaning Florida flip-flopped with ’Bama. Made no sense since all three teams earned quality— but similar — wins over SEC opponents. And seven days later, the Tide proved with their play that it was a strange flip in the Top 25 … It’s not like Spartans head coach Mark Dantonio is soon going to forget his 100th career win since it was an absurd triumph over his team’s instate rival … At the top of the rankings: Seth Russell used his arm (380 yards) and his legs (160 yards) to carry the No. 2 Baylor Bears (6-0) to an easy 62-38 victory over the West Virginia Mountaineers (3-3); the No. 3 TCU Horned Frogs (7-0) shutout the Iowa State Cyclones (2-4)over the final three quarters in a 45-21 win; and the No. 5 Clemson Tigers (6-0) doubled up the Boston College Eagles (3-4) 34-17. THIRD & GOAL Upset of the day: The No. 13 Ole Miss Rebels (5-2) were eaten alive by the host Memphis Tigers (6-0) 37-24 to put a dagger in Mississippi’s national title hopes. Memphis, arguably the best Group of 5 team in the country, is for real with a 13-game win streak … The Kansas Jayhawks (0-6) threw a scare in to the Texas Tech Red Raiders (5-2), who staved off the home-side lesser lights with the help of a crazy two-point convert that saw the centre lateral the snap back to 308-lb. lineman Le’Raven Clark, who then bulled his way into the endzone — usat.ly/1Ppp92e . Texas Tech won 30-20 … Everett Golson had a big day of passing — 26-of-38 for 372 yards and three TDs — to go with Dalvin Cook’s 163 rushing yards and two scores, helping the No. 11 Florida State Seminoles (6-0) turn back the Louisville Cardinals (2-4). FOURTH & INCHES Seldom-used RB Akrum Wadley ran roughshod for the No. 17 Iowa Hawkeyes (7-0), rolling up 204 yards and four TDs on 26 carries in relief of injured star RB Jordan Canzeri to help his club declaw the suddenly-tame No. 20 Northwestern Wildcats (5-2) 40-10 … The No. 19 Oklahoma Sooners (5-1) bounced back after losing to the terrible Texas Longhorns by obliterating the host Kansas State Wildcats (3-3) 55-0 … Not so long ago, the Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets were ranked and a title darkhorse, but a 31-28 home loss to the Pitt Panthers (5-1) gives the Ramblin’ Wreck (2-5) a fifth-straight loss.
